subNodes.conversationText: "What do you want? I thought we were through."
"You said I could eat and rest."
"You can do that later. Middle One will make something for you. Run along now."

"I have told you all you need to know for now. I'm busy." Eldest Lady did not look very busy. She was straightening bottles on a shelf, and that only began after she said she was busy. But the young witch thought better of persisting.
Eldest Lady made it clear that the young witch wasn't welcome at the moment.
"A spirit of the woods told me something interesting."
Eldest Lady looked grim. Middle One fidgeted with a string.
"Then go do what you're supposed to be doing."
"Ah. I hope you're hungry. Middle One has made some food for you. Sit down."
Eldest Lady waved the young witch away. "The day's not done. Do what you can with what's left."
"A spirit of the woods told me something interesting."
"I suppose you're tired," said Eldest Lady disapprovingly.
The witches were sharing a loaf of hard, black bread between them. Though early, the day was already hot, and a light breeze blew in from the yard.
"The day is young, I am old, and you have things to do."
Eldest Lady looked grim. Middle One fidgeted with a string.
"Before Nnenne there was Malkin," put in Middle One.
"He was the third in your coven?"

Eldest Lady only nodded. "He was our third, but he made himself three thirds a problem. We are witches, and we do not think much of what the world thinks is proper. But Malkin was bound by little -- except, of course, his own desires. We couldn't satisfy them. And so -- he left."
"Nonsense. Fantasies. Endless youth, beauty, love." She spat. "Common desires. Mortal desires. He was very powerful and very ignorant."

"And he pursued it as only a fool would -- living in the middle of the woods with two old people, studying witchcraft. Ha! What does the Crone have to do with love? Witches have hearts free from tyranny and minds free from the tyranny of the heart."
"And so he left? Agreed to a coven-breaking?"
"Left? You all agreed to a coven-breaking?"
"Of course he left. We needed Nnenne, didn't we? And now we need you."
"What, exactly, was he looking for? What couldn't you give him?"
"Nonsense. Fantasies. Endless youth, beauty, love." She spat. "Common desires. Mortal desires. He was very powerful and very ignorant."
"I'd rather drop this subject, but if you have anything else to ask about him, go ahead."
"He was the third in your coven?"
"Why did the spirit want me to mention him to you?"
<FirstName> could think of nothing else to ask.
"Well, well, this useless matter has cost you half the day. Maybe that's what the spirits intended. I urge you to avoid them from now on."
"He lives, if that's what you mean. We haven't seen him for many seasons."
"He was the third in your coven?"
"Why did the spirit want me to mention him to you?"
"Well, well, this useless matter has cost you half the day. Maybe that's what the spirits intended. I urge you to avoid them from now on."
"Why would we? Malkin didn't kill Nnenne, of that you can be sure. Avenging our sister is what matters to us."
"So he was the third in your coven?"
"Why did the spirit want me to mention him to you?"
"Why did the spirit want me to mention him to you?"

"The forest spirits know everything that happens here, the secrets of root and stone, tooth and claw. Our secrets, too. They dislike the coven for the same reason an old king looks askance at an ambitious young lord."

"I suppose they've taken an interest in you because you mean to join us." Eldest Lady sniffed. "My guess? They told you about him because they wanted to sow mistrust between you and us. But, as you've heard, Malkin's story, such as it is, has little to do with you."

"Just so: you wouldn't be here if Malkin hadn't left, but beyond that he's unimportant. As for the spirits -- they traffic in secrets. They will try to win you over with trivial ones and betray you and yours when it suits them. Don't let them."
"So he was the third in your coven?"
<FirstName> could think of nothing else to ask.
